CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide
2. PEDOT: PSS: PEDOT: PSS is a conductive polymer, poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate)
3. MoO3: Molybdenum Oxide
4. Al: Aluminum
5. PC71BM: Poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl):2,6-(4,8-bis(5-tert-butyl-2-benzothiazole)benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene):1,3,5-tris(2-phenylbenzothiazole)
6. PBDT-TDPP-S: A novel conjugated polymer, Benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene-Tetrakis(3-thienylcarbonyl)-diketopyrrolopyrrole-Sulfone
7. BHJ: Bulk Heterojunction.

These are the entities that can be identified as "Material Name" in the given paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. ITO
2. PEDOT: PSS
3. MoO3
4. Al
5. PC71BM
6. PBDT-TDPP-S

These are the entities that can be identified as "Material Name" in the given paragraph, which are directly related to the materials mentioned in the text.

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. ITO: Indium Tin Oxide
2. PEDOT: PSS: PEDOT: PSS is a conductive polymer, Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate)
3. active layer: The material used as the active layer in the organic solar cell is not explicitly stated in the text, but it can be inferred that it is a blend of PBDT-TDPP-S and PC71BM.
4. MoO3: Molybdenum Trioxide
5. Al: Aluminum
6. PC71BM: Poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl):[6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester
7. Table 4: A table containing the measured hole and electron mobility values.
8. Figure S7 and Figure S8: Supporting information figures.
9. AFM: Atomic Force Microscopy.
10. PBDT-TDPP-S: Poly(benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene-2,6-diyl-alt-4,4′-(2,2′-diketopyrrolopyrrole-2,6-diyl))-co-[2,2′-bis(3-hexylthiophene-2-yl)vinylenedivinylene]

Properties mentioned in the text:
1. hole mobility: The mobility of holes in the material.
2. electron mobility: The mobility of electrons in the material.
3. FF: Fill Factor
4. PCE: Power Conversion Efficiency
5. surface roughness: A measure of the roughness of the surface of the material.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. PEDOT: PSS: Conductive polymer in the active layer
2. active layer: Blend of PBDT-TDPP-S and PC71BM
3. MoO3
4. Al
5. PC71BM
6. hole mobility
7. electron mobility
8. PBDT-TDPP-S: Side-chain D-A polymer

Paragraph: 1i Figure 4 shows the J-V ( a ) and J 1 / 2 -V ( b ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S devices with a hole - only device configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS ( 40 nm ) / active layer ( varied thickness ) / MoO 3 / Al(100 nm ). Although PBDT-TDPP-S contains bulky and rigid side chains , its blend film with PC71BM exhibited a high hole mobility of 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Moreover , the observed hole mobility is higher than those of the recent reported mainchain D-A polymers , 9 verifying that side - chain D-A polymers can have strong intermolecular orbital overlap and good molecular packing like main - chain D-A polymers. Besides the high hole mobility , the blend also presented high electron mobility in range of 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ( see Figure S7 ). The measured hole and electron mobility are listed in Table 4. Such high and balanced hole - electron mobility for the PBDT-TDPP-S is responsible for the high FF level in the devices. To our best knowledge , the FF is the highest reported to date for side - chain D-A conjugated copolymers The surface morphology of the active layers was studied using atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) under tapping mode in order to further understand why the device exhibited better photovoltaic properties at the annealing temperature of 120 ° C. Figure S8 shows typical AFM topography of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film in unannealed and annealed conditions ( see Supporting Information ). The surface roughness is observed to be 0.773 nm in unannealed condition and 0.602 nm in annealed condition. It indicates that the surface roughness of the blend film can be tuned much smoother by the prethermal annealing. The smooth morphology of the active layer is available for improving the device performance. 10 Therefore , the devices exhibited improved photovoltaic properties by prethermal annealing at an appropriate temperature . In summary , a novel conjugated polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S was successfully obtained , which contains a donor unit of benzo [1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene in main chain and an acceptor unit of diketopyrrolopyrrole in side chain. The resultant sidechain D-A polymer exhibited high carrier mobility and outstanding photovoltaic properties in polymer solar cells with a PCE as high as 4.89% . The PCE level is the highest reported to date in the side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased single BHJ PSCs , which is twice higher than that of the corresponding main - chain D-A polymer - based ones. Our work presented a new promising side - chain polymeric photovoltaic material for high - performance PSCs . Corresponding Author *E - mail : zhuwg18 @ 126.com ( W.Z. ) ; hbwu @ scut.edu.cn ( H.W. ) ; yongcao @ scut.edu.cn ( Y.C. ) .

Let's think step by step.

1. Thickness of active layer: varied (no unit given)
2. Hole mobility of PBDT-TDPP-S:blend with PC71BM, 3.8 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
3. Electron mobility of PBDT-TDPP-S:blend, 4.4 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
4. Surface roughness of unannealed PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film, 0.773 nm
5. Surface roughness of annealed PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend film, 0.602 nm
6. Photovoltaic performance (Power Conversion Efficiency, PCE) of PBDT-TDPP-S: 4.89%
7. Highest reported PCE in side-chain D-A conjugated copolymers based single BHJ PSCs, 4.89%
8. Highest reported PCE in main-chain D-A polymer based single BHJ PSCs (not explicitly stated in the text), < 2.4% (implied by the text stating that the PCE of PBDT-TDPP-S is twice higher)

Note: The values are based on the information provided in the text. Some values are given in the context of comparisons, so I assumed that those values were also mentioned in the text but were not explicitly stated.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.
